title: Latest News from Science Magazine
description: Keyword search result for Alerts: News Weekly Headlines -- New results matching your keyword search query (updated daily).

items.title: As U.S. shutdown drags on, ‘it’s just one blow after another’
items.description: Federal researchers confront growing uncertainty about future

items.title: Perfume scientists tweak cells into having ‘sense of smell’
items.description: A study could transform the lab study of olfaction—and may challenge a Nobel-winning hypothesis

items.title: These ‘ghost flowers’ thrive without photosynthesis. One scientist is learning how
items.description: Japanese botanist Kenji Suetsugu studies plants that steal carbon and nutrients from soil fungi

items.title: What’s it like to tell someone she won a Nobel Prize?
items.description: <cite>Science</cite> chats with photographer Lindsey Wasson, who captured how Nobel winner Mary Brunkow reacted to life-changing news

items.title: In mind-bending twist, ‘magic’ mushrooms evolved twice independently
items.description: Study identifies entirely new suite of enzymes that can make psilocybin

items.title: When women researchers publish, media attention doesn’t always follow
items.description: Men-led papers receive more media coverage than women’s, new study finds

items.title: First approved drug for mitochondrial disease could pave way for more treatments
items.description: Researchers are testing multiple treatments for the rare genetic conditions

items.title: Cuts in global health and climate hit Research Triangle Institute hard
items.description: “Financial drubbing” underscores reliance of some independent research organizations on federal funding

items.title: Long-lived gamma ray burst could signal a new kind of cosmic catastrophe
items.description: Some theorists think unusual event could be a black hole devouring a star from within

items.title: Journals and publishers crack down on research from open health data sets
items.description: PLOS, Frontiers, and others announce policies trying to stem the tide of suspect research
